title: 104_hr3821
content: The Act may be cited as the "Youth Protection From Tobacco Addiction Act of 1996". The Congress finds that cigarette smoking and tobacco use lead to 450,000 deaths annually in the US, costing $65 billion in lost productivity and healthcare. Tobacco products are as addictive as cocaine and heroin. Each day, 3,000 children try their first cigarette, many becoming addicted and dying prematurely. The tobacco industry spends $6 billion yearly on advertising that influences youth tobacco use. The tobacco industry has long denied the dangers of their products, with 82% of adult smokers starting before 18. Voluntary agreements with the industry have been ineffective in curbing youth tobacco use. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON TOBACCO ADVERTISING, PROMOTION, AND PACKAGING. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON TOBACCO ADVERTISING, PROMOTION, AND PACKAGING. It shall be unlawful for any manufacturer, packer, distributor, importer, or seller of tobacco products to advertise or promote tobacco products through free samples, coupons, or sponsorships of events using tobacco brand names or logos. It is prohibited to market nontobacco products bearing the name, logo, or symbol of a tobacco product, unless the brand and corporation existed before January 1, 1996. Additionally, paying for tobacco product placement in entertainment media is also restricted. The marketing of nontobacco products with tobacco brand names is prohibited unless the brand and corporation existed before January 1, 1996. Additionally, paying for tobacco product placement in entertainment media is restricted. It is unlawful to have any human figure, brand logo, or picture on tobacco product packages in the United States. The print on the package must be black on a white background. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over civil actions to restrain violations of section 3. Process can be served on a defendant in any judicial district. Any tobacco product advertised, promoted, or packaged in violation of section 3 is considered a misbranded drug under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The term "tobacco product" includes cigarettes, little cigars, cigars, pipe tobacco, loose rolling tobacco, smokeless tobacco, and any other form of tobacco for human consumption. The term "advertisement" encompasses various forms of advertising such as newspapers, magazines, billboards, posters, signs, banners, and matchbooks. Promotional materials for tobacco products include decals, banners, matchbook advertising, point-of-purchase displays, and other written or visual materials used to promote sales. This also includes advertising promotion allowances and any other means used to encourage tobacco product purchases. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY OF THE FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION and SEC. 7. AUTHORITY OF THE FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION state that existing authority of the Federal Trade Commission and the Food and Drug Administration with respect to tobacco products or promotion shall not be limited or restricted. SEC. 8. PREEMPTION. SEC. 8. PREEMPTION. States and local governments can regulate the location of tobacco advertising and the sale of tobacco products within their jurisdiction as long as it aligns with federal laws. SEC. 9. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not override any requirements of existing federal laws related to cigarette labeling and advertising. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act will take effect 1 year after enactment, with exceptions for advertising on billboards violating section 3 (effective after 2 years) and sponsorship of events by tobacco brands (effective after 3 years or contract termination). The Act will take effect on the date of enactment for events subject to contracts and contract renewals entered into after that date.
